entry.title: Information Overload 2012-09-30
entry.content:
[W]e’re rushing to meet so many deadlines that we hardly register that what we need most are lifelines.

Pico Iyer http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/01/opinion/sunday/the-joy-of-quiet.html?_r=2&pagewanted=all The Joy of Quiet

  • I Was a Warehouse Wage Slave
    This sounds like early 19th century, not early 21st.
  • The Joy of Quiet
    A joy indeed.
  • Clean IT – Leak Shows Plans For Large-Scale, Undemocratic Surveillance Of All Communications
    This reads like a marketing effort for darknets.
  • Meet the Man Who Built a 30-Story Building in 15 Days
    He’s Chinese, in case you wonder.
  • How Did the Duck Hunt Gun Work?
    Another childhood mistery solved.
  • Lettland: Der Musterschüler fällt durch
    Latvia is losing its population due to migration (in German).
  • The drugs don’t work: a modern medical scandal
    Most articles about pharmaceutical companies leave one slightly worried (or worse). This one is no exception.

entry.title: Information Overload 2012-09-23
entry.content:
• “In Wien fehlt der Diskurs zu Gentrifizierung”
    On urban gentrification in Vienna (in German).
  • Odd Things Happen When You Chop Up Cities And Stack Them Sideways
    Great visualization. And wandering around Istanbul is indeed a pleasure.
  • PIN analysis
    Interesting analysis of PIN numbers from a security point of view.
  • “Was the Arab Spring Really Worth It?”: The Fascinating Arrogance of Power
    “Arrogance” really is the only term that comes to mind here.
  • Iran preparing internal version of Internet
    One wonders if they actually think this will work…
  • How Much Food is Eaten Around the World in One Week
    Not really an article, but still quite interesting.
  • The fallacy of the phrase, ‘the Muslim world’
    Well put.

entry.title: Information Overload 2012-09-16
entry.content:
• depression lies
    A very personal blog post by Wil Wheaton, and one I can relate to very much on several levels.
  • Proof claimed for deep connection between primes
    A new important proof in number theory may have been found.
  • Why China still can’t create the next Texas Instruments
    The Electrical Engineering Times looks at why China is not yet in a position to create a company like TI.
  • What Is Seen and What Is Unseen
    What starts as an article about doping, becomes a look at cheating in general.
  • Caribbean Coral Reefs Mostly Dead, IUCN Says
    This is very sad…
  • Crack in Internet’s foundation of trust allows HTTPS session hijacking
    Poor SSL had to put up with a lot these past few years…

entry.title: Information Overload 2012-09-09
entry.content:
I was rather busy this week, so this Information Overload is super short.

  • Condition Handling for Non-Lispers
    If you ever need to explain condition handling to a non-Lisper, this is a sensible post to point them too.
  • IWF-Forscher spielen radikale Bankreform durch
    Two IMF economist test a model where banks can’t create new money in the form of loans (in German).
  • Prehistoric human brain found pickled in bog
    A bit older, but still very insteresting for science.

entry.title: Information Overload 2012-09-02
entry.content:
• The Woman Who Needed to Be Upside-Down
    One of the stranger medical stories I’ve heard so far.
  • CIA interrogation probe ends without any charges
    Everything else would have been rather surprising.
  • «Ein oder mehrere Mitgliedstaaten glauben, dass Sie eine Gefahr sind»
    Brave New Fortress Europe (in German).
  • The humans who outrun horses
    Very interesting article on how humans evolved into long-distance runners.
  • 37signals Earns Millions Each Year. Its CEO’s Model? His Cleaning Lady
    Nice interview with Jason Fried of 37signals fame.
  • DNA test jailed innocent man for murder
    If you have nothing to hide, you have nothing to fear. Yeah, right.
